title: Torque and work - work on wheel from spiral wire

content.question: A wheel can rotate about an axis that passes through its center and is perpendicular to the page. The edge of the wheel is attached to one end of a wire that is connected to a motor, which is fixed in place. The motor exerts a force on the wire such that the wire exerts a counterclockwise torque of magnitude <math alttext="tau sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> about the center of the wheel when the wheel is at an angular position <math alttext="theta sub 0 equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. As the wheel rotates, the torque exerted on the wheel changes as a function of <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> that is given by <math alttext="tau equals tau sub 0, end sub, e raised to the negative theta over k power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>τ</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>τ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></msup></math>, where <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> is a positive constant. If the positive direction for <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> is counterclockwise, how much work is done by the wire on the wheel as the wheel rotates from <math alttext="theta sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> to an angular position <math alttext="theta sub f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math> ?

<math alttext="Tau sub 0, end sub theta sub f, end sub, e raised to the negative theta sub f over k power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>f</mi></msub><mo>/</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></msup></math>
